awd_titl_txt: Development, Deployment, and Evaluation of Instructional Modules for Current and Future Practitioners of Model-based Systems Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to the national need for well-educated engineers and technicians in production engineering.  It will do so by supporting the design, deployment, and evaluation of online modular courses in model-based systems engineering. Given the increasing complexity of manufactured products, engineers with expertise in model-based systems engineering practices are critical to maintain U.S. competitiveness in manufacturing and related industries. Over three years, courses will be developed for three populations of learners:  two-year college students, four-year college students, and working professionals.  The project will be conducted by Purdue University in collaboration with Ivy Tech Community College and several industry partners to ensure that the courses are integrated across student levels and well aligned with both students' degree programs and industry's needs.  Course materials will be divided into modules, allowing students and professionals to personalize their learning by taking the modules most important to them.  These learners will also be able to certify competence in areas of their own choosing.  The instructional materials to be developed will advance technical education and provide students with virtual experience in real-life settings. This project will enable students to engage in the course materials remotely, making them accessible to thousands of students and professionals across the country. Moreover, educational techniques developed as part of this project might be adapted for teaching other technical skills, expanding the benefits to other U.S. industries and workforce members.

The overall goal of this project is to develop a set of effective, scalable online instructional materials in model-based systems engineering.  The materials will be based on current research on student-centered education in authentic settings. There are three specific aims. The first is to identify the key concepts students must master in model-based systems engineering. The second is to develop pedagogies for teaching the concepts effectively to students at two-year, four-year, and professional levels. The third is to develop a process for assessing the effectiveness of online technical instruction for students with different experiential and demographic backgrounds. Social learning theory suggests that students learn through engaging with each other and the course material in a learner-centered approach. This approach has been demonstrated to improve student learning and persistence in face-to-face technical courses, but little is known about how it can be incorporated into online learning or what effect it has.  The project will investigate the effectiveness of the approach in an online setting for diverse groups of students at different levels, from first year college students to practicing engineers. 

This project is funded by NSF's EHR Core Research: Production Engineering Education and Research (ECR: PEER) program, which seeks to improve the education of future and current professionals in production engineering. It also aims to study the effectiveness of the innovative educational strategies adopted by these projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Model-based systems engineering (MBSE) is a relatively new approach to manufacturing which has been shown to significantly reduce the time and cost to move a product from initial design to full-scale production.  The traditional manufacturing process involves designing the product, building a prototype, testing it, evaluating its performance, making modifications, and perhaps testing again before beginning production.  In MBSE, a digital model is constructed, tested using a computer simulation of conditions under which a product might be used, making modifications to the model as needed, and iterating until the product is ready for production.  Engineers with various areas of expertise, often sitting in offices thousands of miles apart, can work together on the model, and when they are finished, everyone involved in manufacturing the product can use the same model. 

Companies now have the computer hardware and software and the databases needed to create and test products without actually building them, saving time and money.  The other essential ingredient required to implement MBSE is a workforce that knows how to use the digital models to do their part in the manufacturing process.  Obviously, engineers need to know how to use the software to develop accurate models and test them, but others need to know how to use the models as well.  They include the technicians on the factory floor who use the model to prepare their machines to manufacture the product, the procurement people who use the model to order required materials and parts, the sales force members who use the model to demonstrate the product’s capabilities to potential customers, and the managers who use it to plan and cost the production run.

Our project had two primary goals.  The first was to develop, deploy, and evaluate online instructional modules that would provide those already employed in manufacturing and those interested in that career path with information and skills they will need to work in an MBSE environment. The second goal was to provide information others could use to develop equally effective online instructional materials in additional technical areas.  To meet the first goal, we developed a suite of seven online instructional modules that address various aspects of working in the MBSE environment. Someone interested in learning about MBSE can take all seven modules or just the ones of interest to them.  The modules are described here.  In addition, the materials used in the online modules are available for downloading at no cost through a Creative Commons License.  The materials can be found here.  Finally, the first module, which is an introduction to systems thinking, systems engineering, and MBSE, has been incorporated into some Purdue courses likely to be taken by students interested in careers in manufacturing, thus helping to prepare them for working in an MBSE environment.

We met the second goal by publishing articles and making presentations at conferences that provided information on how we prepared a well-defined set of MBSE-related concepts employers expected their employees to understand and skills they expected the employees to possess. We developed that list through a series of carefully designed, focused interviews with MBSE champions in several companies and some government agencies.  We also described how many of those champions provided continuous input as we developed the instructional modules.  In addition, our project team included several members with expertise in preparing, presenting, and evaluating online instruction in technical fields.  We published and presented papers and conducted a workshop on preparation and evaluation of online instructional units on technical material.  Finally, the de-identified data we used in evaluating our online instructional modules has been deposited in the Purdue University Research Repository where it is accessible by anyone who would like to conduct additional analyses.

Our work on this project is expected to have broader impacts than the immediate ones described in earlier paragraphs. Individuals, organizations, and society in general can benefit from our work. Professionals and students who become familiar with MBSE and the tools used in the MBSE environment will be valuable to their employers and will be better positioned for advancement in their organizations. An improved understanding of MBSE among the workforce will make U.S. manufacturers more competitive in the world market, benefiting the U.S. economy and society as a whole.  One characteristic of effective instructional materials is that they are designed to engage and encourage learners from all backgrounds which, in the case of our modules, can increase the size of the workforce prepared for careers in manufacturing in an MBSE environment.
